div1.head: Mac to M. Paul Rockwell April 26th 1915
div1.p: Ca va, tris doucement, comme un soldat, Mon vieux.

Well we are where we wanted to get and in a position to do really useful work. If we were any nearer we’d have to crawl in the trenches. At our base we are fixed up in fine shape. I’m billited [sic] on two old souls who have given me a bed and who look after my few wants. Now and anon the Germans give us a party and bang away. The other day they turned loose at the station. Two little children who were playing in the street were killed by an obus. I went down to see the damage and heard the mother up above us crying over the bodies of her only boy
and girl. It was very pitiful. The next morning before I was up eight more shells came in. The nearest was about four hundred yards from us. It killed an old woman. The entertaining part about the game is that you don’t know where they’re going to land, as you know well. I could hear a faint, distant boom, then a suction sound followed by the tearing ziff, ziff, ziff as the damned obus came towards us. It was comforting to hear the crash and to know it hadn’t landed on my house.

On the way to our advance post there is a kilometere [sic] of road that is shelled. Our convoy spreads out and kills it along
that part. Our advance post is under a good deal of fire. The other day 126 shells landed in the berg. Our quarters there are very comfortable, but draughty [sic], due to the shell holes. We have mattresses out there in a room that looks out on the German lines 1,400 yards off. We could be potted by rifles if the Boche thought it worth while.

The day before yesterday I met an American that looked as if he had just stepped off Broadway. His clothes were typically American and his trousers were turned up, and pressed! I wondered what he could be doing away out there. It seemed so
queer to see this immaculate person around. It developed that he was an engineer on a big job near there and has stuck to his post during the war. He saw the German occupation and the battles that followed. His views and tales are very interesting. Decker is the fellows name.
We are informed that we can expect a bunch of Taubes [sp ?] late this after- noon and a large fight soon after.
